poem:
The Coin and the Lions  

Bailey wonders, whose hands  
could hold a coin so grand—  
the size of a bike's tire,  
spinning in sunlight's choir.  

And lions, count them,  
mane by mane, in quiet dreams—  
kings of gentle vastness,  
roaming where the past is.  

This is the world,  
in questions of the young,  
as large as wonder sprung.
